description: I am certainly no medical expert, but I am becoming ever more dismayed by the increasing acceptance amongst the public, that things will never be the same again, or acceptance of the“ new normal”. ¨I lived through the virulent Hong Kong flu epidemic of 1969, which swept the world, and resulted in the UK having between 30,000 and 40,000 ¨excess deaths, with the NHS...
text:
I am certainly no medical expert, but I am becoming ever more dismayed by the
increasing acceptance amongst the public, that things will never be the same
again, or acceptance of the "new normal".¨I lived through the virulent Hong
Kong flu epidemic of 1969, which swept the world, and resulted in the UK
having between 30,000 and 40,000 ¨excess deaths, with the NHS being put under
extreme pressure.¨I do not recall hardly any alterations to daily life, with
businesses, pubs, restaurants and sport carrying on more or less as normal.

There was no "social distancing" or the wearing of hideous masks.¨The main
difference was that we didn't have the internet, social media, or 24 hours of
scaremongering news ¨channels, which has resulted in paranoia and fear,
gripping this country.¨I have spoken to several ¨people who are old enough to
have experienced the 1969 epidemic, and without exception, they had all
forgotten about it!¨This country needs to knuckle down to trying to get back
to the "old normal".

Glyn D J Linder,

Shirley Close, Frettenham.

Can I send out an appeal to fellow readers to put aside coronavirus and
Cummings et al for a few minutes every day to help our garden wildlife?¨The
continuing hot weather is causing the ground to be rock hard with little water
and food around for wildbirds and hedgehogs. Please help ¨them survive by
putting ¨water out daily in a flat container (like a plastic flowerpot holder
or old dinner plate or roasting dish) for drinking and bathing.¨Also kitchen
scraps, seed, breadcrumbs and so on will be gratefully received by birds
struggling to feed themselves and nestlings.

Hanging feeders containing sunflower hearts and suet fat balls will attract
goldfinches, sparrows, starlings and more.¨If you are lucky enough to have
visiting hedgehogs, a little dog or cat food will be welcome in addition to
water.¨Please help our wildlife survive this dry spell.¨On a happy note, it's
wonderful to see swifts returning to our skies, cuckoos calling in Broadland
and even a lone heron feeding with swans on Wroxham bridge - must be the lack
of holidaymakers in these current troubled times.

Even waterbirds need a helping hand with bread and seed on occasion!

Jillian Hollis-Graves,

Cuttons Corner, Hemblington.

One of the most extraordinary aspects of the "Cummings affair" is the total
lack of insight shown by his supporters in expecting the public to believe
their hugely implausible justifications.¨A senior bishop expressed this as
treating the public like mugs. For a bishop to make such a comment is
unprecedented; but we are living in extraordinary times.¨When will politicians
realise that you cannot defend the indefensible?¨Loyalty will metamorphose
into stupidity and ultimately stupidity will not help their naked ambitions.

C J Rumball,

Strumpshaw.

In seeking to explain their somewhat ill-considered actions in the current
crisis those in authority are often using the word "integrity". Dominic
Cummings, according to the prime minister, acted with "integrity". Health
Ministers claim that their policy towards care homes has been undertaken with
"integrity".¨Playing football behind closed doors at neutral stadiums is to
preserve the sport's "integrity".¨There now seems to be an interesting attempt
to redefine the meaning of this word.

John Bradford,

Roseacre Close, Norwich.

title: Knuckle down ¨and get back to the ‘old normal’
html:
I am certainly no medical expert, but I am becoming ever more dismayed by the increasing acceptance amongst the public, that things will never be the same again, or acceptance of the “new normal”.¨I lived through the virulent Hong Kong flu epidemic of 1969, which swept the world, and resulted in the UK having between 30,000 and 40,000 ¨excess deaths, with the NHS being put under extreme pressure.¨I do not recall hardly any alterations to daily life, with businesses, pubs, restaurants and sport carrying on more or less as normal.

There was no “social distancing” or the wearing of hideous masks.¨The main difference was that we didn’t have the internet, social media, or 24 hours of scaremongering news ¨channels, which has resulted in paranoia and fear, gripping this country.¨I have spoken to several ¨people who are old enough to have experienced the 1969 epidemic, and without exception, they had all forgotten about it!¨This country needs to knuckle down to trying to get back to the “old normal”.

Glyn D J Linder,

Shirley Close, Frettenham.

Can I send out an appeal to fellow readers to put aside coronavirus and Cummings et al for a few minutes every day to help our garden wildlife?¨The continuing hot weather is causing the ground to be rock hard with little water and food around for wildbirds and hedgehogs. Please help ¨them survive by putting ¨water out daily in a flat container (like a plastic flowerpot holder or old dinner plate or roasting dish) for drinking and bathing.¨Also kitchen scraps, seed, breadcrumbs and so on will be gratefully received by birds struggling to feed themselves and nestlings.

Hanging feeders containing sunflower hearts and suet fat balls will attract goldfinches, sparrows, starlings and more.¨If you are lucky enough to have visiting hedgehogs, a little dog or cat food will be welcome in addition to water.¨Please help our wildlife survive this dry spell.¨On a happy note, it’s wonderful to see swifts returning to our skies, cuckoos calling in Broadland and even a lone heron feeding with swans on Wroxham bridge – must be the lack of holidaymakers in these current troubled times.

Even waterbirds need a helping hand with bread and seed on occasion!

Jillian Hollis-Graves,

Cuttons Corner, Hemblington.

One of the most extraordinary aspects of the “Cummings affair” is the total lack of insight shown by his supporters in expecting the public to believe their hugely implausible justifications.¨A senior bishop expressed this as treating the public like mugs. For a bishop to make such a comment is unprecedented; but we are living in extraordinary times.¨When will politicians realise that you cannot defend the indefensible?¨Loyalty will metamorphose into stupidity and ultimately stupidity will not help their naked ambitions.

C J Rumball,

Strumpshaw.

In seeking to explain their somewhat ill-considered actions in the current crisis those in authority are often using the word “integrity”. Dominic Cummings, according to the prime minister, acted with “integrity”. Health Ministers claim that their policy towards care homes has been undertaken with “integrity”.¨Playing football behind closed doors at neutral stadiums is to preserve the sport’s “integrity”.¨There now seems to be an interesting attempt to redefine the meaning of this word.

John Bradford,

Roseacre Close, Norwich.
